response_parsed.title: Deep Dive: signal Standard Library Module in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This guide provides an in-depth exploration of the signal standard library module in Python 3.12+, focusing on its features, usage, and important updates.
key_points: The signal module allows for communication between a process and its children, typically used for handling asynchronous events such as signals or exceptions.
Python 3.12 introduces several new signal-related functions, including SIGRTMIN and SIGRTMAX which provide more fine-grained control over real-time signals.
The signal module can be used to create custom exception handlers for specific signals, providing a flexible way to handle different types of asynchronous events.
Python's signal module is particularly useful in applications that require low-latency responses or real-time processing.

code_examples.code:
import signal

sigint_handler = lambda signum, frame: print('Caught INT or TERM signal')
signal.signal(signal.SIGINT, sigint_handler)
signal.signal(signal.SIGTERM, sigint_handler)

version_notes: Python 3.12 introduced SIGRTMIN and SIGRTMAX signals for more fine-grained control over real-time signals.
Python 3.10 added the signal.setrecursionlimit() function to change the maximum recursion depth of a thread.
caveats: Be cautious when using signals in production code as they can potentially cause unintended side effects if not properly handled.
Some operating systems may not support all signals, so it's essential to consider the specific environment in which your application will run.
